capacity is significantly reduced relative to your actual usage so it reacts dynamically to changes in load

continuous usage and as a result I want to make sure that I'm got it turned on all the time AWS won't you give me a
deal and the answer is yes we will in exchange for you making a commitment to us to use our resources will give you a

you can imagine when we're working with millions of customers around the world we needed some excess capacity ourselves
at the top of what we offer because we want to make sure that our customers all of them don't max out right the weed
that we don't run out of capacity so we have spare capacity and we auction that off to you we'll tell you a little bit

booking that at a lower cost meanwhile I also have peaks of usage over and above that base and I could use on-demand
instances for that and again we're not talking about different instances we're just talking about different payment model right so if you've committed to a
hundred hours of a particular instance type in a month and you consume 101 hours then a hundred hours would be
billed at the reserved instance rate and that one hour would be billed at an on-demand rate so once you understand
your usage pattern you can make a commitment and you can go from there right so these these are key things to
understand why would you do that I referred earlier to the fact that there's some savings

three years and importantly it's just not just ec2 they're available in certainly the relational database

rules the first is spot market pricing changes right this is all about supply
and demand and if the if the supply of the the particular instance type that you're interested in goes down the price
is going to go up and it could go beyond the point that you're willing to pay so you bid a price let's say you bid 20
cents per hour for a particular instance if the market is dictating the price is
10 cents you only pay 10 right you bid 20 but you only pay 10 it goes up to 11 you pay 11 it goes to 12 you pay 12 so
you pay the market price right up to the point of achieving your bid at the point
where the the price dictated by the market goes higher than your bid you're gonna get notice that you're gonna
basically be kicked out of those instances and then you need to put in place a process to either get ready to
shut down your workload or to migrate it to an on demand situation or or take
another action whatever makes sense to you but because you get these notices programmatically you're programmatically
